pros: Large range of work. Lots of freedom and flexibility. Contact with graduate students. Possibility to teach on the side. Friendly people (but that might depend on the team). Possibility to write or participate in research papers. Access to conferences and occasional classes.
cons: Salary lower than in the private industry (as comparable position: Software Developer). Less insurance, less perks, have to pay for coffee, no bonuses. Research professionals are not professors, not students, and do not always have the same advantages as other regular employees. They tend to "fall between the cracks" in the eye of the employer.

review_title: The job has been satisfying in that it
pros: Location is one of the pros. Despite being situated in one of the quieter districts of the island of Montreal, it is at the same time at the center of all the necessities of daily life like stores, banks, hospitals, etc. Another pro is its calm environment and relaxed atmosphere. Yet another pro is the opportunity it provides for learning or working in French for those interested.
cons: Life can be difficult in this place if your French leaves something to be desired. The place is on top of a hill and there are a number of electrical escalators inside the buildings. When they go out of service either because they break down or because they need regular maintenance, you have to climb many stairs. I am not sure about personnel turnover in this place. But normal routines seem to suffer as a result of too many switches and/or exchanges and/or departures/arrivals.

pros:
-Great people
-Lots of resources
-Unionized

It's academic. Though it can be hard to achieve full professor or find a position as an associate professor, it is an enjoyable place to work.
cons:
-The primary building feels old
-The cafeteria is subpar (Aramark)
-Accessibility to the office can be tricky and annoying (On a hill, near other universities and hospitals). Finding a parking spot on the street is impossible. Paid parking is expensive and limited. Best to come by subway or bike.

pros: People will always try to help you. If you choose your supervisor wisely the experience will be great.
cons: Salaries are variable, no clear chart for salaries. You may do a phd with no financial problems or you may spend your time trying to find funding. It depends on your supervisor.

review_title: As a post doc is hard
pros: Depending on the group, the infrasctructure is great and so are the collegues.
cons: Unfortunatelly there was a negotiation regarding the worker status and it was the worst. Now we have a more than 30% cut off the salary even for ongoing contracts. 30% off your salary, 2 months advice....

review_title: Great place for research - except when you have to deal with HR human/financial services .
pros: You are surrounded by top researchers. Constant access to seminars, conferences, etc.
cons: Dealing with the human/financial services is a mess... Everything takes ages and is done last minute (probably under staffed), and in a University with so many international people I would expect more English speaking personnel.

review_title: Doing Postdoc is great if you want to continue in academic. If you want to go industry do not do that
pros: Good Environment. No time limits. Free to work at home. Good vacation time, usually more than 1 month.
cons: Making you lazy for looking for a real industrial job. Besides, it makes you over qualified for most industrial positions.

pros: One of the best engineering school in Canada, academically.
cons: Very French, English graduates find difficulty in finding a job in Montreal, but out of Montreal, it's reputation is not appreciated.

pros: Many great professors that take the time to help and guide their students, while leaving them do to their own research. Many possibilities of scholarships and opportunities of internships during the graduate studies.
cons: Like any University, some teachers do not teach well, but most are OK.
